original: Unlike other large U.S. airlines which mostly use hub-and-spoke systems, Southwest uses point-to-point operations and underwent a massive crew scheduling "meltdown" because most of its pilots and flight attendants were out of position, which resulted in massive numbers of flight cancellations persisting for days after the worst weather had subsided and other airlines had largely recovered.
simplified: Other U.S. airlines use hub-and-spoke systems of operations while Southwest uses point-to-point operations. || Southwest had a big problem with crew scheduling because most of its pilots and flight attendants were not where they were supposed to be. || This caused a lot of flights to be canceled for days after the weather got better.

original: Unlike other large U.S. airlines which mostly use hub-and-spoke systems, Southwest uses point-to-point operations and underwent a massive crew scheduling "meltdown" because most of its pilots and flight attendants were out of position, which resulted in massive numbers of flight cancellations persisting for days after the worst weather had subsided and other airlines had largely recovered.
simplified: Unlike other large U.S. airlines which mostly use hub-and-spoke systems, Southwest uses point-to-point operations. || Because of this, many of its pilots and flight attendants were out of position, which caused a lot of flight cancellations. || Many of these flight cancellations continued for days after the worst weather had gone away.

original: Unlike other large U.S. airlines which mostly use hub-and-spoke systems, Southwest uses point-to-point operations and underwent a massive crew scheduling "meltdown" because most of its pilots and flight attendants were out of position, which resulted in massive numbers of flight cancellations persisting for days after the worst weather had subsided and other airlines had largely recovered.
simplified: Southwest Airlines uses point-to-point operations rather than the hub-and-spoke system used by other U.S. airlines. || They had a "meltdown" of crew scheduling which caused a lot of flight cancellations, even after the worst weather had passed and other airlines had recovered.

original: Unlike other large U.S. airlines which mostly use hub-and-spoke systems, Southwest uses point-to-point operations and underwent a massive crew scheduling "meltdown" because most of its pilots and flight attendants were out of position, which resulted in massive numbers of flight cancellations persisting for days after the worst weather had subsided and other airlines had largely recovered.
simplified: Unlike other large U.S. airlines which mostly use hub-and-spoke systems, Southwest had a massive crew scheduling "meltdown" because most of its pilots and flight attendants were out of position. || This resulted in massive numbers of flight cancellations for days after the worst weather had passed and other airlines had largely recovered.

original: Unlike other large U.S. airlines which mostly use hub-and-spoke systems, Southwest uses point-to-point operations and underwent a massive crew scheduling "meltdown" because most of its pilots and flight attendants were out of position, which resulted in massive numbers of flight cancellations persisting for days after the worst weather had subsided and other airlines had largely recovered.
simplified: Southwest airlines cancel a lot of flights for a few days even after the worst weather had reduced. || This happened because Southwest uses a different system for scheduling flights than other major airlines. || Instead of using big transit centers, Southwest's flights go directly from one place to another. || Because of this, many of the pilots and flight attendants were not in the right place, which caused the cancellations.
